title: Carmel Myers
text:
Carmel Myers (April 9, 1899 – November 9, 1980) was an American actress who achieved her greatest successes in <a href="silent%20film">silent film</a>.
Early life.
Myers was born in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>, the daughter of Isidore Myers, a <a href="Russian-Jewish">Russian-Jewish</a> <a href="rabbi">rabbi</a> who was born in Russia but raised in Australia, and Anna Jacobson Myers, an <a href="Austrian-Jewish">Austrian-Jew</a>. She had an older brother, Zion, and she was a cousin of director <a href="Mark%20Sandrich">Mark Sandrich</a> and photographer <a href="Ruth%20Harriet%20Louise">Ruth Harriet Louise</a>. Carmel's father was active in campaigns for <a href="women%27s%20suffrage">women's suffrage</a>, abolition of capital punishment, and <a href="zionism">zionism</a>. He also was a noted scholar. The family moved to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> in 1905.
Myers attended <a href="Los%20Angeles%20High%20School">Los Angeles High School</a> but left after <a href="D.%20W.%20Griffith">D. W. Griffith</a> gave her bit part in the film "<a href="Intolerance%20%28film%29">Intolerance</a>" (1916), for which her father was an unpaid consultant. She continued her education at a school for young actors.
Myers helped her brother become a writer and director in Hollywood.
Career.
Silent film and theater.
Myers left for New York City, where she acted mainly in theater for the next two years. She was signed by <a href="Universal%20Studios">Universal</a>, where she emerged as a popular actress in <a href="vamp%20%28woman%29">vamp</a> roles. Her most popular film from this period—which does not feature her in a vamp role—is probably the <a href="romantic%20comedy">romantic comedy</a> "<a href="All%20Night%20%28film%29">All Night</a>", opposite <a href="Rudolph%20Valentino">Rudolph Valentino</a>, who was then a little-known actor. She also worked with him in "<a href="A%20Society%20Sensation">A Society Sensation</a>". By 1924, she was working for <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a>, making such films as "Broadway After Dark", which also starred <a href="Adolphe%20Menjou">Adolphe Menjou</a>, <a href="Norma%20Shearer">Norma Shearer</a>, and <a href="Anna%20Q.%20Nilsson">Anna Q. Nilsson</a>.
In 1925, she appeared in arguably her most famous role, that of the Egyptian vamp Iras in "", who tries to seduce both Messala (<a href="Francis%20X.%20Bushman">Francis X. Bushman</a>) and Ben-Hur himself (<a href="Ram%C3%B3n%20Novarro">Ramón Novarro</a>). This film was a boost to her career, and she appeared in major roles throughout the 1920s, including "<a href="Tell%20It%20to%20the%20Marines">Tell It to the Marines</a>" in 1926 with <a href="Lon%20Chaney%2C%20Sr.">Lon Chaney, Sr.</a>, <a href="William%20Haines">William Haines</a>, and <a href="Eleanor%20Boardman">Eleanor Boardman</a>. Myers appeared in "<a href="Four%20Walls%20%28film%29">Four Walls</a>" and "<a href="Dream%20of%20Love">Dream of Love</a>", both with <a href="Joan%20Crawford">Joan Crawford</a> in 1928; and in "<a href="The%20Show%20of%20Shows">The Show of Shows</a>" (1929), a showcase of popular contemporary film actors.
Sound films, radio, and television.
Myers had a fairly successful sound career, mostly in supporting roles, perhaps due to her image as a vamp rather than as a sympathetic heroine. Subsequently, she began giving more attention to her private life following the birth of her son in May 1932. Amongst her popular sound films are "<a href="Svengali%20%281931%20film%29">Svengali</a>" (1931) and "<a href="The%20Mad%20Genius">The Mad Genius</a>" (1931), both with <a href="John%20Barrymore">John Barrymore</a> and <a href="Marian%20Marsh">Marian Marsh</a>, and a small role in 1944's "<a href="The%20Conspirators%20%281944%20film%29">The Conspirators</a>", which featured <a href="Paul%20Henreid">Paul Henreid</a>, <a href="Peter%20Lorre">Peter Lorre</a>, and <a href="Sydney%20Greenstreet">Sydney Greenstreet</a>.
In 1939, Myers performed for 13 weeks on the Resinol radio program that was broadcast twice weekly from station <a href="KHJ%20%28AM%29">KHJ</a> and carried on the <a href="Don%20Lee%20Network">Don Lee Network</a>.
In 1951, Myers had a celebrity interview TV program, "The Carmel Myers Show", on <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>. In 1952, she formed Carmel Myers Productions, a firm for producing radio and TV programs. The company's productions included "Mark Hellinger Tales", a transcribed series of 30-minute radio dramas with Edward Arnold as narrator and "Cradle of Stars", a 30-minute filmed TV series with Gregory Ratoff as director and star.
Later, she focused on a career in real estate and her perfume distribution company. In 1976, Myers was one of the very few silent stars who were cast in "<a href="Won%20Ton%20Ton%2C%20the%20Dog%20Who%20Saved%20Hollywood">Won Ton Ton, the Dog Who Saved Hollywood</a>", a comedy featuring cameos by dozens of Hollywood stars of the past.
Book.
In 1952, Doubleday & Company published "Don't Think About It", a 64-page book by Myers. Based on her experiences following the death of her husband, the book related her philosophy for emotional survival after a person has a tragedy in his or her life.
Personal life.
Myers married attorney and song writer Isidore "I.B." Kornblum on July 16, 1919; they divorced in 1923.
Myers and attorney Ralph H. Blum married on June 9, 1929, and had three children: author Ralph H. Blum (born 1932), known for his works on divination through Norse <a href="runes">runes</a>, and two adopted daughters, actress and radio personality Susan Adams Kennedy (born 1940) and television producer Mary Cossette (born 1941). Myers and Blum purchased <a href="Gloria%20Swanson">Gloria Swanson</a>'s <a href="Sunset%20Boulevard">Sunset Boulevard</a> home.
On October 30, 1951, Myers married <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount Pictures</a> executive Alfred W. Schwalberg in Brooklyn. They were married until his death in 1974.
Death.
Myers died of a heart attack on November 9, 1980, in Los Angeles Medical Center at the age of 81. She was buried near her parents at <a href="Home%20of%20Peace%20Cemetery%20%28East%20Los%20Angeles%29">Home of Peace Cemetery</a> in East Los Angeles. Her epitaph reads "L'Chaim", which in English translates to "To life".
